description.text: An EGR Model

title: HiFi-Pi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Still searching for a Headless Raspberry Pi case for your Pi with Display / Volumio-Pi / MPD-driven mediaplayer? Here it is:
The HiFi-Pi!
= The HiFi-Pi-Case is a Case which snaps together, is suitable for wall-mounting, has it's I/O on the bottom, and only has the important plugs on the outside: Power and audio. It's designed to run headless, without LAN, HDMI and so on. Things you Need:
  • a PI (model B; B+ should also work but untested)
  • an USB-DAC (i used this one: http://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00BBCXVG6/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 , and removed the casing)
  • a display (STLs made for a hd44780-20x4, but a 20x2/16x2 will also work is you modify the corresponding part in the scad)
  • a small usb-wifi-adapter(e.g. the cheap edimax ones)
  • a dc-hollow-jack, 2.1mm (or with whatever you want to power-provide your PI with)
  • an audio-distro for your PI like volumio (or self-configured; whatever...)
  • M3x6 screws and washers, nuts..
  • Short, old USB-Cables or parts of them for inner USB-cable routing
    • The case can be modified through the scad-file; however, its not fully parametric, but i added it anyway for smaller adjustments like changing the display size. i made the little tray an extra part, so that you don't have to hassle with several hours of reprinting, when your soundcard or your powerjack might not fit. also this small part can easily be redesigned to fit your hardware. Feel free to remix, and please let me know if you managed to make one of this cases, i will soon add a version of the top-part for buttons.

Be careful when snapping the two parts together, depending on your layer-lamination the snap-clips might break apart! The Power jack should be glued in. it just provides the best connection. I actually zip-tied the sound-card to the tray, but i think finally i will hot-glue it, to avoid pushing the soundcard in when plugging the jacks. to keep the display free from active parts, you can add a ~150ohm(depends on your display) resistor to the contrast, for me it has the right contrast for readability. (hd44780: resistor between P15 and VCC) I stripped some cables of, it just fits better. In a closed case its unneccessary to use bulky plugs everywhere, so i directly soldered the power-in-usb-jack to a dc-jack; to one of the usb-ports i soldered an USB-cable to be able to re-route the USB-DAC to the tray. printed in black PLA, ~50mm/s speed, 20% infill, 0.35mm nozzle and 0.25mm layers

comments.text:
uhm, i got snippets of this (i think) from the volumio-forum, but to make this short:
if your familar with linux its easy: get yourself an mpd installed, wifi on, network-share for your music and "mpdlcd" as LCDd-clients which pushes mpd-infos to the display, i dont really have a step-by step-manual, you have many way to get this running, i took volumio because i like the mpd-webinterface, but on a 1st-gen-PI its horibbly slow, so maybe your feel better with raspian+mpd+LCDd+mpdlcd+"AnyNotTooUglyMpdWebInterface". just google for the hd44780-raspberry wiring, this is not too coomplex, and interchangeable for all this kind of pi-projects...

comments.author: ikester

comments.text: This case doesn't fit the Raspberry Pi B+ or 2 version boards, and will actually damage components on both if the top is pressed to "snap" onto the bottom with a Pi board inside. The pads at the rear of the case where the original screws were used are too wide, and make contact with L2 (marked "4R7", a 4.7uH choke). If the top of the case is pushed down, the corner of the choke casing will chip off. Damage can be avoided by trimming the pad area with a hobby knife by about 1/16".
comments.author: Technopope

title: Self Watering Herb Garden and Spice Space

description.text: This a small self watering container for growing herbs on your counter top as well as a space to keep your most used spices handy. It is designed for dual extrusion.

A self watering container allows moisture in the bottom of the container to soak into the potting soil and rise as needed to each of the plants. 1) fill the bottom planters with potting mixture
2) place the lid on top and fill the planting towers with potting mixture.
3) plant your herbs of choice in the towers
4) fill the base with water - an overflow hole will prevent you from over filling the planter (but not from making a mess!)
4) wait for your herbs to grow
5) refill the base only as needed (once a week or so)
6) enjoy the fruits of your printing labors!

This one needs a lot of reworking to work properly. I was trying to create a clip for the filament spool not to unwind during storage or swap out. It failed. Wow. This one has the wrong name on the file. Just saw the preview and this is the Tri-Angler brace to hold the filament spools during printing. The scale is off. I printed something close to this and it failed in a couple of ways. The ABS print became so brittle due to lack of moisture that it snapped apart very easily. In should be increased in size by 50%-100%. One of the interesting things I noticed after playing with the temporarily successful prints was that this could be the foundation of an open-toy construction toy project. Not just this file, the one I actually printed. Fully modular with quick connects and many, many combinations. I will be sinking some serious time into the open-toy project after I get back into the design time.

This "wheelbarrow" for a heavy stand mixer allows you to easily move the mixer under the counter or into a corner. It can be printed in a color to blend (or contrast) with the mixer.

Print the rear base/axle at 100% fill for axle durability. It works at 10% fill, but a safety factor wouldn't hurt.  
Push skateboard bearings into the wheels, then push the wheels onto the axle. Connect the front base and rear base with the connector (friction fit).

comments.text: I love this idea--if it was a little flatter and used a lot less plastic I would be printing it right now! I wonder if it would be possible to do something similar in a more minimalist way by just putting wheels on the back and something in the front to level it without needing a whole supporting platform.
comments.author: FireflyII

comments.text: I think your idea would be more attractive than mine and use less plastic.  My mixer is sort of "hollow" on the bottom so the front piece would have to conform to the front curves of the mixer. Another idea I didn't develop that might be worthwhile--take some furniture slides (those squares used for moving heavy furniture) and place a couple on the back, then one toward the front with a 3d printed "pull/push" tab.

Enclosure for Digital Temperature Controller
================================= This is an enclosure for one of those cheap Chinese digital temperature control units sold on Amazon and eBay. These devices sell for about 20 Euro and are really good for controlling a heating or cooling unit. WARNING: Main voltage is deadly! Don't attempt this unless you know what you are doing!
I am not a trained electrician. The instructions below may be wrong or even dangerous.
.
.
.
I will not grant Thingiverse any rights to my source files so please go here for the Solidworks part files
https://github.com/KaiserSoft/3D-Printing
Required Parts

• 1x cheap Chinese temperature controller
  • 1x 2,5mm² terminal block strip with 6 terminals
  • 220V cable
  • 1x fuse according to load. I used a 3A fuse here
  • 5x M3x20mm screws to secure the lid
  • 3x 2mm self tapping screw to secure terminal strip
  • 2x 3mm or larger zip ties to secure mains lines
  • 1x 2mm zip tie to secure temperature wire
    • Build Instructions

Warning There are different versions of the temperature controller. Some have different outputs and some require 12V to run. Always check the manual that came with your unit for the correct wiring diagram!!! I am using model MH1230A in this example. It connects directly to mains and can switch loads of up to 30 amps.
  • Print Lower v2.stl and Lid.stl using 0,25mm layers, 20% 3D honeycomb infill, 1 outside shell, 2 top/bottom layers and a heated bed.
  • Wire unit according to the wiring diagram that is included with your unit
  • Secure incoming cables with zip ties on the inside. This prevents any cables from being ripped out of the unit.
    • Warning This unit will disconnect whatever is connected to terminal 1. The output pin of your connected load may be hot if your country does not use keyed outlets. Germany does not, so I marked the location of the phase on my plug and check the outlet with a phase detector before connecting the unit.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116042 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=116042

This is the site of a deadly 2012 avalanche. The features of the map are not scaled up, i.e. I left the output at 1X because I was interested in the geographical features of the area. It is constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 2.6 million polygons). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA on the Makerbot 2 and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I am printing now with a Taz 5 and I can print larger maps with the heated bed.

author: mdenton

description.text: This is my test piston I made for a 1" schedule 40 PVC pipe. I cut and spliced (2) 3/16" O rings (cut length 70mm) for this, and it threads onto 1/4-20 threaded rod. I tested this, putting it in a pipe with about 10" of water over it and left it for about 24 hours, no leakage, so I'm decently pleased with it so far. With a little oil, it takes about 2 pounds to move the piston. I hope this could take shop air (120 psi), I think it could. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:717976 for O Ring Splice Jig See my blog entry at http://ryanfabrications.blogspot.com/2015/03/piston-test-print.html

Print,
Make sure it fits in your PVC pipe,
Tap hole with 1/4-20 threading tap,
(optional) Coat with polyurethane or very diluted PlastiDip,
Affix O Rings,
Attach to rod,
and Done

title: Ferrari F1 Steering wheel (Logitech G25 base)

description.text: NEW VERSION http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1513508 (NOW OSW COMPATIBLE)

Complete F1 wheel to replace the original G25.
Second version of other wheel made time ago.
The hotbed in my prusa I3 is a 20x30cm now and is possible to made the body and cover parts complete.
Even the body and handles fit!!
In the first one with a default 20x20 bed i split them in two.
If i found the olds STL´s i promise upload them.The images with the wheel finished are from this version.
I use a quick release from http://simulaje.blogspot.com.es/ to change the rims easily for other tipe of car (i like rally games too:) but the wheel could be mounted to the G25 base permanently with the original screws if you plan to drive F1 cars only. CHECK FOR UPDATES!!!

19/03/2015
Added new cover version CoverF15Fullv2.stl with a recess of 0.5 mm to put the tags of the rotarys. 17/03/2015
Uploaded repaired file BodyF15Full_repaired.stl with the nuts to fix the cover in the correct place (back)and some errors in the stl removed.
PLEASE DOWNLOAD THIS.
17/03/2015
Uploaded another version of the body and handles,F15Plano.stl and ManetaF15Plano.stl.
Every handle comes in two halves,so 4 parts required.
Print 2 as is and 2 mirrowed.
If you want to apply Plastidip easily use them.You can hot glue them together with the body.
The part CoverF15Full.stl is compatible with this version. 12/03/2015
New version of the knobs uploaded!!!
knob_ferrari_v9.stl with a hole to slide a m3 nut.I use v8 before without a nut since the screw only fix OK.Better solution instead.
Drill he hole with a 3mm bit.
knobv8.stl clean from holes in the shell.I printed v7 the first time with no problems,but just in case. 11/03/2015
New files uploaded!!!
Cover and handles now 0.5 and 1mm tighter.Easy to put together with the body(Less file time work)
11/03/2015
Added some images of the previous model and some of the printed pieces of the V2.
11/03/2015
Uploaded a full body (BodyF15full.stl)with the handles attached.REMOVED
*File with errors.Download the new file repaired.Sorry for the inconveniences.** A 20x30 bed is needed.A new cover (CoverF15full.stl) uploaded too.

Printer settings: Printed with Cura 14.01 ALL PARTS EXCEPT THE DISPLAY COVER AND KNOBS
E3d Volcano 1mm nozzle and 30 mm/s speed.
PLA 100% infill,0.5 layer height.(0.3 with a 0.4 extruder.From 50% infill is OK too)
The handles need support.30% is OK.Print flat.
If you choose the full body version,use the same settings too.Beware the thing eats up 750gr of PLA with 100% infil.A complete spool!!!
You can lower to 50% instead for both parts body and cover.
For the plain version use the same settings too.Support 30% DISPLAY COVER AND KNOBSv7
E3d v5 0.4 nozzle 30 mm/s speed.
ABS 30% 0.1mm layer heigth.Print as the image with 20% support. KNOBFERRARI AND KNOBLATERAL
Same settings above,no need support. The reason for ABS is give the parts a acetone vapor bath,but feel free to made it of PLA too.

title: Flexible filament guide for CraftUnique Craftbot

description.text: This is a "snap in" guide to allow the use of flexible filament (Ninjaflex, Filaflex, etc..) with the CraftUnique Craftbot.  This unit fills the gap between the top of the thermal tube and the feed/idler wheels.  That constrains the filament so that it has less of an opportunity to buckle and deform during the extrusion process.  It mimics the filament guide used on other printers such as the Makerbot R2X.

I have printed this in PLA @ 200 microns on the Craftbot and in ABS (adjusted for thermal shrink) @ 178 microns on my MBI R2X.  Both with 25% infill, 3 shells.  The details was a bit better in PLA, but the ABS will probably give better long term durability.  
I "clean up" the bore with a 2mm drill.  
Remove the filament, fan, and left bracket screw on the CB.  The guide should "snap" onto the thermal tube.  It fits perfectly on my machine but I don't know how the assembly variances are on the CB.  
The drive wheel set screw may interfere with the guide.   You can either relieve the guide to provide clearance, or remove the set screw and grind down the non-socket end by ~1mm.  I didn't want to relieve the guide model for this clearance since I was concerned about printing integrity.  
Check for interferences after installing and make sure your drive and idler wheels rotate freely.  Running a PLA print through the unit will help to "burnish" the bore and prepare it for your flexible filament.

author: greenbeats

description.text: This is just a simple Jig to help splice O Rings. The slots in it are for O Ring sizes 1/8", 3/16", and 1/4". http://ryanfabrications.blogspot.com/2015/03/piston-test-print.html I do not certify any effective sealing pressure with O rings joined this way. I used this O rings to seal water at atmospheric pressure, you shouldn't risk it for anything that could cause injuries unless you are satisfied with how the system was made.

This may need some filing to get the carriages to slide on the track. But otherwise... O Ring Splicing:
Step 1. Cut O ring cord to length (70mm shown in pictures). Try to keep cut as square as possible. Step 2: Press ends of O ring cord in groove as shown. Step 3: Apply small amount of Super Glue to the O Ring joint, then slide the carriages closer so the O Ring is butted up. Use a Q tip to draw away any excess glue. Step 4: Let dry, and file any rough edges away from joint. Hope this helps if anyone wants custom O Ring sizes or doesn't want to buy hundreds at a time.

title: Stepper to Camera - Universal mounting plates

description.text: A set of mounting plates and low profile modular dovetail adapters for attaching a range of cameras to a NEMA 17 Stepper Motor. Ostensibly for the purpose of creating a single axis gyro stabilised mount for all standard cameras. The 90 degree dovetails allow you to adjust the mount to adjust the axis of the lens to that of the motor, to avoid a swinging motion (or to add one, if that's your preference). Inspired by Derek Leiber's awesome gyro mount for the Contour (http://www.revenanteagle.org/checksix/gyrocam/), I decided I wanted one that works on any camera up to small DSLRs, to this purpose I'm moving up to a NEMA11/17 stepper motor for extra torque, and building it as a universal system that could be used for other purposes, like automated panoramas. Stepper motors are a bit jerky compared to servos so you'll ideally want a 1/16 microstepping driver like the Pololus used by the RepRap project. A 400 step (0.9 degree) motor should then yield a resolution of 6400 steps over the whole rotation. If this still proves to be too jerky a geared down stepper motor could easily be adapted (and provide even more torque).

UPDATE: The first draft of the 5mm shaft adapter is up, there have also been changes to the dovetails (some rounding and such). The motor mount has now been updated to use the mounting format of the other parts, this makes it possible to add an extra, positionable axis!  
The male and female dovetail plates are joined to the shaft mount or themselves by epoxy glue or similar, using a short snip of 1.75mm filament in each of the four corner holes. These function as indexing and strengthening lugs. Being square they can either be built with the dovetails in the same direction or at 90 degrees to give two axis adjustment.  
Still to come is a hollow to house an M3 nut between the plates so a grub screw can be used to lock them down.  
The male dovetail is 0.25mm smaller than the female to allow easy mating. Still, I have found that they benefit from some smoothing.  
It's probably best to print the dovetails with no bottom infill, to allow the epoxy to get a mechanical grip on the infill.

These parts are the X End Motor Carrier and the X End Clamp for Mendelmax 1.5 for 10mm rods in X and a LM10UU bearing in Z direction!   
I'm building my own Mendelmax 1.5 at the moment with only 10mm rods. So I had the problem, that the original parts don't fit very well. To solve the problem I constructed my own parts following the example of Kludgineer.  
If there are any questions, write me a message.

• Print both parts

author: pk_47

description.text:
This is an adapter to give my drill press a manual handle mount. This allows me to chuck a tapping bit and use it to create very perpendicular taps. This was made for a Central Machinery 5 Speed Bench Drill Press, Harbor Freight
http://www.harborfreight.com/8-in-Bench-Mount-Drill-Press-5-Speed-60238.html Blog Entry
http://ryanfabrications.blogspot.com/2015/03/tapping-drill-press-handle.html

Print off Components.  This component may not work with all drills, but adjust/design accordingly  
Disconnect Drill Press (Keep disconnected while using the manual handle)  
Clamp to the Top Pulley on the Driven side of the Drill Press using some 1/4" bolts (about an 1" Lg).  Tighten.  
Attach magnet to handle.  
Make sure handle mates up (Kinda loose) to the pulley clamps.  
Chuck a tapping bit and clamp the workpiece accordingly.  
Use one hand on the drill press lever to keep pressure on the workpiece.  
Use other hand to manually turn the tapping bit.  
Return handle to storage location after use.  I leave my clamps on during drill use, they don't do anything when the drill is on but spin.  
This has helped me get good perpendicular threads with the drill press I already own.  I think the handle could be better, but its a start

comments.text: For PLA, that's fine, but for steel and others, its nice to have a better grip.

description.text:
There are loads of coin holders on Thingiverse, and for loads of different currencies - but not too many for UK coins. So here is my contribution. There's even a slot for folded bank notes if you're lucky enough to have some.  
I've uploaded the sketchup file so you can adapt it if you want. Don't forget to print at 102% if you're using ABS otherwise the coins won't fit!  
I've just uploaded a larger version which also has a £2 coin slot.

Just remember to print at 102% in ABS as the internal diameter dimensions have to be large enough to accept the coins.  
The sketchup file is there too so you can add someone's name on the back to personalise it.  
This version is a bit tight for the 50p's so I'd go bit larger and print at 103%-104% or go in to the sketchup file and make the hole a bit bigger.

title: Solar Eclipse Canon 18-55 DSLR lens filter holder

description.text: This is a hood for a canon 16-55mm DSLR zoom lens with a diameter of 58mm for solar eclipses. You have to apply the AstroSolar film yourself

Use double sided sticky tape on the (square) top of the "solar-lenscap-bottom.stl" thing. stick the BAADER AstroSolar Safety film on top of the double sided sticky tape. and snap on the "solar-lenscap-top" Then hang it inside the ring of your lens. It should fit snugly and not immediatly fall out. IF this is not the case. Consider using double sided sticky tape on the edges of the ring to keep it in place. I wanted to share it because of the solar eclipse next week I'm also working on an iphone 6 holder for this type of foil. Source for the film:
http://www.robtics.nl/product_info.php?products_id=1339

description.text:
Behold: My entry into the FirstBuild/Thingiverse kitchen countertop challenge!  
This is an expandable table/cake plate. When folded, the skirt measures 75mm in diameter. When expanded, the table is 100mm in diameter.  
Everything has .2mm tolerances. Not sure how much it needs. It's currently 100mm fully expanded, but could easily be scaled up to 200 or 300 for a cake plate sized table, and still printed on a small printer.  
The design is based very loosely on a Fletcher-Capstan table, which was loosely based on a design patented in 1835.  
The Fletcher-Capstan table has 962 components, and mine has 22 (28 if you have to print the larger pieces in quarters). Also, mine doesn't spin - not as fun, but I was on a 2-week limit here! I think I beat the size expanded/size folded over the 6-sided Fletcher-Capstan table, though.  
All of the parts have .2mm tolerances, and are aligned in such a way as to make them easily 3-d printable. They all should slip fit into each other. There are individual pieces in different STL files, in case your printer has issues, or in case you need to print out the larger pieces in 1/4 size and glue together.  
There are only 22 (28 plus glue?) pieces. The pieces, design, and tolerances have taken me more than a week straight to design, redesign, and throw out entirely.  
The skirt is not attached, but slip fits over the pieces when folded or unfolded. There are 4 large and 4 small rail things. Assembly is completed by pushing the rail pieces into their respective holes in the base, slipping one leaf at a time on from the center, then fitting them all on. The skirt supports for when the table is folded simply slip underneath.  
I am so glad to get this done! I've put a ton into this! Thanks for the challenge, Thingiverse and FirstBuild!  
Edit: I'm entry number 250! Too cool!
Made in Rhinocerous 5 - 2-d drawings started in AutoSketch 9.

I present to you the V-ship. My own design with many cool features in mind.
The front motors are pushers which are tilted slightly forward for better thrust. The back motors are the known V-tail design and the mid motors just over CG are to be connected in parallel with the front motors and rotate the same way. It should be controlled with the normal hexacopter configuration and higher pitch propellers on the back. There is a mount for a fatshark (or other ) CMOS or CCD sensor and for a strap holding a Mobius below. Space for FPV system is left below the tail and above is for placement of the battery yet to be printed and built As of march 29
Now all files are back up. Sorry to everyone they where not available, I made a mistake. Feel free to print!
"platta v2" has bigger antenna wholes and a little larger support. Also improved the easiness of print around the camera mount. As of march 15
bak v2. There was an access problem with the rear getting the screws in place. This update should fix that problem.
Print preferably in ABS with high or full infill. Motors to be used are 2204 about 2000-2300kv with 5x3 props besides the back which should use 5x4.

comments.text: I really like the idea, but I have to say I question the functionality... The back two motors, especially on a tilt, will not provide ample thrust to counter act the 4 front motors. Also, I'm not sure how you plan to run the 4 front motors in parallel pairs. Connecting 2 to each esc would not work, and neither would connecting both signal plugs to the flight controller. I'd suggest running it as a hex setup on a flight controller such the kk2.1.5 on which you can controller how much controller each individual motor has over thrust, yaw(rudder) etc. You'd have to set it to a hex setup, and then reverse the two upside down motors' directions so they act as if they are right side up. You'd give the back two almost 100% control over yaw movement, and it would still fly as a vtail, and you'd have to expirement with how much thrust power/control to give each motor to balance it out. With the middle two near the axial CG, currently if the back two and front two had the same thrust power, it would just do somersaults if it even managed to get in the air, since the tilted motors would provide so much less upwards thrust. Then, you'd have to lower the thrust range of the front two until they were balanced out with the back two, and the middle two could possible stay the same and act as upward thrust control only. And with the thrust of 4 full motors, and less thrust from two, and are lowering the thrust of the front two, then say you have 5 motors worth of thrust total with that but you are still drawing 6 motors worth of power. Basically you wouldn't be able to carry a large enough battery to have acceptable flight times. Those are just my thoughts on how you could actually make this work, although I love the design!
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text: also, looking at more of the pictures, you may get unwanted vibrations in the tail end.
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text:
Your worries have reason. I have been thinking about the design for quite some time and I know it might need some programming. The forward motors have almost 100% thrust even being tilted 12 degrees (98% thrust) while the back only give 70% with 45 degree tilt. It means the back motors need to work exactly 40% harder witch can be regulated with either the placement of the battery or with gain in software. Though if the differences get small it might not need compensation.
Regarding the two mid motors, if they are close to CG they wont interfere with the control. If they are connected in quadx setup then the z-axis (axis of rotation or yaw) of the copter would be somewhere between the CG and the back as well as the pitch which might be a little unresponsive. The roll will have no negative effekt being in quad configuration.
Using 5x4" props in the back and 5x3" on the rest will compensate for the lost 40% thrust and hex setup might work good as well
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text: That mostly makes sense, though I still cant figure out how you'll run the motors in parallel. I dont think you can Y split the servo plug for control, mainly because the power will be split and the frequency messed up. Let me know what you come up with! Should be interesting :)
comments.author: philsson

comments.text: it depends on where the CG is placed. Take a look at the 5 armed tricopter. You might be right anyways and I am also not fully sure about my assumptions, but hexa setup should be quite easy.
comments.author: loganj13

comments.text: Yup hexa should work well.

title: ZIM refillable filament cartridge V2 with integrated dust-remover and exchangable beak

description.text:
Here you are... A working alternative to Zeepro's original cartridges.
This one can be fed from the top, so the cartridge could stay inside the printer, while you only have to exchange the spools.
Also, the original beaks wear off pretty fast, so this cartridge has an exchangeable beak which is designed to allign with the cartridge-body automatically. The spool-part has to be printed twice, just clip the two parts together. For the RFID-Chip: Due the RFID-chip is programmable, just cut it from an old original cartridge (be sure not to damage it!) and put that piece into the cartridgebay under the printed cartridge. So you can re-program it anytime you want. If you have suggestions or improvements, please let me know. EDIT: I reworked the body (added a chamfer for easier beak-installing) and the cover (it's now upside down for easier printing). The beak (also modified for easier printing) now has enough space for a piece of a sponge (just cut it a little bit bigger than the hole in the beak and cut it in half before inserting) to remove dust from the filament. Be sure to use the "Beak_for_sponge_EZ-Print.stl" for dust-removal-capability. EDIT AGAIN:
Due to multiple requests of a single person, I added the "old" Versions of the beak without space for the dust-sponge (cartridge_V2_beak.stl).

Just print all the parts from the package (Print the spool twice!) and clip them together (okay, the spool parts have to be glued... yet.
The cover is not necessary to operate the cartridge, but it looks much more professional... Old version of some parts:
1: Choose beween the clipable OR the glueable version of the spoo and print it twice
2: Choose between the beak with space for a sponge or without

title: The Happy Helper - Counter Top Waste Collection Attachment

description.text:
This two part counter-top attachment utilizes plastic grocery bags to create a portable waste container where you need it most. Simply slide the Happy Helper base onto your counter top, place an empty plastic grocery bag inside the large opening, and snap the top on to sandwich it in place. When you are finished with the bag, twist it closed, unsnap the attachment, and dispose of in your normal waste bin.  
The cantilever design clip is standardized for 1.5" counter tops, and when both pieces are connected the Happy Helper is the same height as a 1/2" cutting board.  
The protrusion is rounded both for safety and to maximize design without sacrificing material cost to print. All extensions are reinforced with fillets, and there is a slight transition fit to snap the top and bottom pieces together and maintain alignment.

title: In Cabinet Roller Holder and Cutter

description.text:
A very basic roll holder for Aluminum foil, parchment, cling wrap, etc. Basically print two Roller Spindle brackets, one Guide Track, and one Cutter, mount the spindles and the guide to the inside of the cabinet using #6 hardware, mount a standard exact-o knife blade to the cutter (you'll need to drill a small hole in the cutter) with the blade inside one of the slots in the cutter, and then slide the cutter onto the track. Note, you can print as many spindles as needed and reuse the same cutter.   
Open a box and put the roll onto the spindles. When you want some aluminum foil or plastic wrap just pull down, slide it into the guide, pull out the amount you want, and then slide the cutter across to cut to size while holding the sheet taught. Warning the exact-o blade is exposed when cutting so take precautions. When not in use slide the cutter all the way over until the blade is in the knife cover.

description.text: This mounts to the normal Z switch mount and allows you to adjust it with precision. I use a clamp to jam a nut in the small piece. With a screw to get it lined up just right. Then a nail file to make them fit , but snugly inside each other. The bottom support was added after testing mine at .4 infill without it and observing twist. This prevents twisting which would introduce error. The little holes may need drilling, the big ones should be fine for the spring screw. You want it to be really tight so vibration wont make it turn. Print at 1 infill.

author: Nipoutch

title: QU-BD X,Y Bed Extender & bed riser

description.text:
These parts will allow you to extend the X and Y of your bed.   
You will loose some Z. The reason for the loss is to get the bed above the bearings and the printer base.

Just print the needed parts. Remove the upper bed. Then clip the bearings free. Once the lower bed is removed. Line up bed extender with the old mount. Drill holes. Screw tight.   
Add the bearing risers and mount on base with zip ties.   
Complete reassembly.   
Remove timing belt from old mount. Mount timing belt and secure with printed clamp. Verify everything fits and works.   
When operation is verified. Disassemble again. Cut off old mount. Reassemble.   
You now have a larger printing area.   
You can also purchase a mirror to fit the new larger area.

author: j42398

description.text:
I have not printed it myself yet - but thought I would share the design so far - the full thing or in 3 printable parts (you will need an 8mm x 150mm steel rod & 6off 5mm x 20mm dowel pins - or you can try to print them) 16/03/15
Early days, just printed the prototype (took a good 7 hours) and although the print is not as good as I hoped (few gaps) it’s not too bad – needs a bit of acetone to smooth it out before spraying with silver metallic car paint. Realised the 3 sets of holes only allows as I designed or 120deg rotation of the parts – so not so good for the 1/10 left handers out there – sorry about that, I didn't mean to discriminate. So I might change that and have two or four holes. Also the parts don’t properly mate (flatness of the top and bottom) – very slight gap between them, probably my printer or print settings – not sure if I should put them in the lathe to finish the face off or to use an Acetone slurry to fill the slight gaps. Another thing I noted was the ribs on the base part could have printed better so I might make another version such that the ribs are printed separate and can be glued on using 416 Next step – fill the gaps or machine, mask the ribs and spray metallic silver Any feedback is always welcome to help progress the design Thanks ME!!

author: stefi01

title: Spool Holders for current gen (March 2015 ...) Flash Forge Creator Pro

description.text: The new stock spool holders are 50mm in diameter.  So they only fit a limited range of spools.  Here are 30mm and 18mm rods mounted to the same brackets as the new stock ones.  The 30mm rods are the same diameter as the old stock ones.  The 18mm rods are for smaller spools like t-glas, etc.

You want to print either or both of the rods and one hanger for each.  Snap the hanger tabs into the rod base slots and you'll end up with the same kind of "horizontal slot" the current FF CPro printers use.  Personally, I also glue them together.  
I suggest printing both the rod files with support which will act as infill for each base section.  20% support fill seemed enough for me.  You may be able to use even less.  While I haven't tested, I'd also suggest at least 4 permieter shells and 33% layer infill for strength.  
The rods are designed to work well with spring clamps, as shown.
